I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Thailand has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide technical assistance (TA) for supporting more balanced development of the Thai capital 
market, increasing the range and sophistication of financial products, and strengthening the 
existing  institutions  and  policy  framework—making  the  Thai  capital  market  more  efficient, 
competitive, financially sound, and responsive to global trends.  
 
2.   The  2007–2011  country  partnership  strategy1  identifies  capital  market  development 
among the core areas of cooperation between Thailand and ADB, and it is a top priority on 
Thailand’s domestic economic agenda. The TA project is included in the TA pipeline for 2008.2 It 
is the second of four TA projects expected for Thailand over the medium term to deepen bond 
and equity markets, broaden the investor base, strengthen financial stability, and enhance risk 
management practices in the financial sector. This TA project aims to build on previous ADB 
advisory TA that addressed weaknesses in important areas of capital market operations, and 
laid the groundwork for the capital market to play an even stronger role in supporting Thailand’s 
economic development. A reconnaissance mission from ADB visited Bangkok, Thailand from 26 
March to 1 April 2008 to discuss the desired focus and expected results of the TA with the 
Government and other key stakeholders. This report reflects the findings of the mission and the 
understandings reached with the Government on the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference of the TA. The TA design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  While  the  capital  market  has  grown  substantially,  loans  from  financial  institutions 
continue to be the major source of private sector financing. As of 2007, bank financing to gross 
domestic product (GDP) amounted to 86% while equities market capitalization was 71% and the 
bond market 54%. Thailand market capitalization ($203 billion) ranks far below Hong Kong, 
China ($2,177 billion); Republic of Korea ($960 billion); Singapore ($486 billion); and Malaysia 
($290 billion). Share turnover velocity (71%) compares closely with Singapore (77%) but is 
below that of the Republic of Korea (195%) and Hong Kong, China (99%). Secondary trading of 
stocks by retail investors represents about 54% of daily trading value. Despite the high level of 
activities in the secondary market, the investor base is still restricted to about 480,000 individual 
brokerage accounts and about 80,000 accounts for mutual funds—representing only 2% of the 
total  population.  The  institutional  investor  base  is  still  underdeveloped.  The  Government 
recognizes that the Thai capital market needs to increase the range and sophistication of 
financial products, and to strengthen the existing institutions and policy framework. The capital 
market investor base, comprising both institutional and retail investors, needs to be broadened 
further. Improved access to debt, equity, and risk management products is required to support 
higher levels of economic growth and investment.  
 
4.  The TA report for supporting implementation of the capital market development master 
plan3 was submitted to the Government in November 2007 and was received very well. Many of 
the report’s recommendations have been, or are, in the process of implementation. The very 
satisfactory implementation of that TA has enhanced the value of ADB interventions in the 
financial sector/capital markets in Thailand and encouraged the Government to request further 
TA  to  lead  to  more  balanced  development  of  the  Thai  capital  market  and  make  it  more

2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 June 2008.

competitive internationally. In this context, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the Bank of 
Thailand (BOT) have requested expanded TA to cover some of the more difficult practical 
aspects of the implementation program and to build on progress already made. They wish to 
build  professional  capacity  within  their  institutions  to  implement  these  reforms  and  have 
requested focused assistance in the following areas. 
 
5.  Public Debt Management Office. A key amendment to the Public Debt Management 
Act (2007) allows the Government to issue government debt for bond market development 
purposes, regardless of the budget position. Surplus cash flow from issuance will be placed in a 
bond market development fund, which needs to be managed effectively to minimize the cost of 
issuance  to  the  Government.  It  is  hoped  that  the  fund  will expand  its  asset  and  liability 
management capability so that it will make a return for the Government. Assistance is required 
to develop the fund’s risk management and investment capacity so that fund surpluses may be 
used more constructively. Assistance is also required to develop an accounting system and 
procedures to operate the fund on a sustainable basis. 
 
6.  Although the auction process is relatively well defined, some areas need to be further 
streamlined. The process of debt consolidation, currently under way, needs to be undertaken 
concurrently but gradually. This would have a positive impact on liquidity in government bond 
markets. Cash management practices in the Public Debt Management Office (PDMO) also need 
to be streamlined. In addition, assistance is required to establish procedures for onlending and 
develop a framework for guarantees to state-owned enterprises and local government units. 
  
7.  Fiscal Policy Office—Capacity Building in the Bureau of Savings and Investment 
Policy. The Fiscal Policy Office (FPO) is often required to play an advisory role in development 
of the financial sector/capital markets in Thailand. To carry out this role effectively, there is a 
need to strengthen the technical knowledge and skills of staff in the Bureau of Savings and 
Investment Policy to interact effectively with other relevant government agencies and market 
intermediaries  in  the  capital  market  and  to monitor  the  development  of  capital  markets  in 
Thailand more constructively.  
 
8.  Fiscal  Policy  Office—Secondary  Mortgage  Corporation. This  was  set  up by  the 
Emergency Decree on Secondary Mortgage Finance Corporation B.E. 2540, 1997, as a state 
enterprise under MOF with capital of B1,000 million. Its objective was to become the Thai 
equivalent of Ginnie Mae4—taking mortgages originated by the Government Housing Bank and 
other commercial banks, and securitizing them. However, Thailand has seen a relatively small 
number of securitization transactions as banks and finance companies identify securitization as 
a last resort for raising finance. There are no balance sheet constraints, and the size of assets is 
taken as an indicator of strength rather than weakness. Under the current scenario, there is a 
need  to  define  the  role  of  the  Secondary  Mortgage  Corporation  (SMC)  clearly.  A  holistic 
evaluation of SMC needs to be carried out, in terms of its future positioning, shareholding and 
organizational structure, products to be offered (including credit enhancement), and building up 
institutional capacity to enable SMC to become a viable entity and justify its mandate in leading 
the development of the securitization market in Thailand.  
 
9.  Securities and Exchange Commission of Thailand. The Securities and Exchange 
Commission  (SEC)  has  worked  closely  with  the  Federation  of  Accounting  Professions  in 
improving the Thai accounting standards, auditing standards, and code of ethics for accountants 
to align it with revised international standards. In 2006, SEC set up the International Financial

United States.

3 
Reporting Standards (IFRS) and the International Standards on Auditing (ISA) monitoring panel 
to study and express opinion on the IFRS and the ISA. SEC wishes to design procedures for an 
independent review of audit practices adopted by auditors of listed companies, i.e., their work 
process and systems (including building of relevant databases, format of reporting, internal 
quality assurance system, and enforcement).  
 
10.  The  Stock  Exchange  of  Thailand—Capital  Market  Development.  To  be  globally 
competitive,  The  Stock  Exchange  of  Thailand  (SET)  is  pursuing  three  major  strategies 
simultaneously:  (i)  promoting  capital  market  development,  (ii)  restructuring  SET,  and 
(iii) improving  the  exchange  alliance  with  regional  stock  markets.  ADB  is  supporting 
restructuring of SET through the services of an international consultant, guiding the direction of 
an ongoing study. It is also supporting the exchange alliance process through regional TA 
(RETA) for enhanced cooperation among Southeast Asian equity markets.5 Thailand was a key 
player in setting up the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Capital Market Forum 
whose focus is mutual recognition and harmonization of standards of information disclosure, 
accounting standards, credit rating, and cross-border recognition of qualification and experience 
of market professionals, among fellow member countries. ADB is proposing to support these 
initiatives through RETA for strengthening Southeast Asian financial markets, which is being 
processed. 
 
11.  In terms of capital market development, SET will play an important role as one of three 
co-secretariats of a newly formed Capital Market Development Committee.6 The committee is 
considering  the  development  of  a  comprehensive  and  systematic  master  plan7  for  capital 
markets by the end of October 2008. The plan will embrace all relevant dimensions including 
the equity market, bond market, derivative market (including commodities), and money market. 
It will aim to develop a comprehensive plan for the Thai capital markets for the next 10 years 
(2009–2018) and provide a degree of certainty to the direction of the Thai capital market, 
thereby creating more sophisticated capital markets in Thailand. Other proposed measures to 
develop different segments of the market will be reviewed in the process, including coordinating 
with BOT and SEC. SET requires support for developing the master plan. 
 
12.  Bank  of  Thailand—Mortgage  Insurance.  BOT  requires  assistance  to  develop  an 
efficient mortgage insurance system in Thailand to protect lenders and investors against loss 
caused by borrower default in situations where the home value (net of foreclosure-related costs) 
is  insufficient  to  repay  the  mortgage  obligation  fully.  Thai  commercial  banks  usually  grant 
housing loans based solely on the collateral of borrowers, within the loan-to-value limit of each 
bank. Currently, total housing loans amount to B771,142 million and have the potential to 
increase over time, while the nonperforming loans are about B34,650 million or 4.5%. BOT is 
keen to improve risk management in commercial banks on housing loans through mortgage 
insurance.  
 
13.  Bank of Thailand—Exchange Control Policy. Thailand had resorted to imposition of 
various  capital  controls  and  measures  to  prevent  currency  speculation,  which  inevitably 
produced a negative effect on the development of its financial and capital markets. The capital

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
14.  The  TA  will  help  develop  a  functional  internationally  competitive  capital  market  in 
Thailand. The expected outcome under the TA will be generation of secure and diverse funding 
sources that support basic capital and investment needs.  
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
15.  The TA will consist of the following components: 
 
(i)  Public Debt Management Office. This component will build on work carried out 
under  TA  supporting  the  implementation  of  the  capital  market  development 
master  plan  (footnote  3),  and  improve  the  structure  of  the  bond  market 
development fund and the bond issuance program under the new amendment. It 
will  also  help  establish  the  framework  and  procedures  for  onlending  and 
guarantees to state-owned enterprises and local government units. It will assist in 
developing the new framework for cash management of PDMO. This component 
will  develop  a  debt  consolidation  and  issuance  strategy,  and  streamline 
government auction processes.  
(ii)  Fiscal Policy Office. This component will provide the following: 
(a) Support for capacity building by helping develop staff skills in FPO to 
interact effectively with the market and monitor the development of capital 
markets in Thailand more constructively.  
(b)  Support to SMC by carrying out a holistic evaluation of SMC and identifying, 
if appropriate, measures to revive SMC based on a sustainable business 
model.  
(iii)  Securities  and  Exchange  Commission.  This  component  will  help  design 
procedures for an independent review of audit practices adopted by auditors of 
listed companies. Workshops will be held to train SEC on compliance with the 
IFRS and the quality control system in accordance with ISA 220 and ISQC1.8 
(iv)  Stock Exchange of Thailand—Capital market development. This component 
will help draft a master plan to achieve the objectives identified by the Capital 
Market Development Committee, which will include measures to (a) deepen the 
securities market; (b) offer high quality securities, including risk management, 
through new products; (c) expand the investor base and improve measures for 
investor protection and education; (d) improve competition and enhance market 
intermediaries and related institutions, including supporting market infrastructure, 
leading to reduced transaction costs; (e) improve regulation and coordination; 
(f) facilitate integration to global capital markets; and (g) carry forward the study 
done under TA supporting implementation of the capital market development 
master plan (footnote 3) to help develop a liquid and integrated capital market

(v)  Bank of Thailand. This component will assist BOT to do the following: 
(a) Mortgage insurance. Develop an efficient mortgage insurance system to 
protect lenders and investors against loss caused by borrower default.  
(b)  Exchange  control  policy.  Balance  the  conflicting  policy  objectives  of 
developing  Thailand’s  financial  markets  while  ensuring  its  ability  to  manage 
speculative capital inflows effectively. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost a total of $1,450,000 equivalent, of which ADB will provide 
$1,000,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The 
Government will provide the remaining $450,000 equivalent by providing counterpart staff and 
other support facilities. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  Given the diversity of components (para.15), the TA will have three executing agencies 
(EAs). PDMO under MOF will be the EA for components (i), (iii), and (iv); FPO will be the EA for 
component (ii); and BOT will be the EA for component (v). It is expected that coordination of the 
outputs will be achieved through the Capital Market Development Committee. 
 
18.  The TA will require 28 person-months of international consultant inputs and 13 person-
months of national consultant inputs. It is expected to be implemented over 12 months, from 
July 2008 to June 2009. Consultants will be engaged on an individual basis in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) because of 
the wide diversity of expertise needed. Outline terms of reference are in Appendix 4. 
 
19.  The  consultants  will  be  required  to  submit  inception  and  interim  reports  within  the 
deadline specified in the work plan agreed with ADB. Draft final reports will be submitted within 
the deadline specified after incorporation of feedback from the EAs and ADB. Forums on capital 
market development for policy makers and regulators (such as MOF, BOT, and SEC, as well as 
SET,  Bond  Electronic  Exchange,  Thai  Bond  Market  Association,  and  Thailand  Futures 
Exchange) and market participants (such as the issuers, financial intermediaries, and investors 
of the capital market) will be held during TA implementation. The consultants for component (iv) 
will  present  the  TA  findings  and  the  proposed  plan  of  action  for  addressing  weaknesses 
identified in the Thai capital market. Based on this presentation, the participants will discuss 
courses of actions to be taken to formulate and implement the reform measures. The draft final 
report, including a blueprint for the capital market and the sequenced action plan for undertaking 
the required reform measures, will be submitted before a specified deadline. In parallel, the 
consultants working on components (i), (ii), (iii), and (v) will submit separate periodic reports (to 
be agreed during inception) to their respective EAs. The TA outputs will be published on the 
Government’s website.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Thailand for Capital Market Development Phase II and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Individual consultants will be recruited to implement this TA. The international capital 
market development expert will be the team leader for all tasks to be carried out under the 
technical assistance (TA) project—except components (ii)(b) and (v). The TA deliverables are 
detailed under para. 15 of the main text of this report.  
 
A.  International Capital Market Development Expert and Team Leader 
(4 person-months) 
2.  The team leader is expected to have significant recent expertise (10–15 years) in capital 
market development. Experience in the Asia and Pacific region is preferable. The team leader 
will be responsible for preparing a comprehensive and systematic master plan for the Thai 
capital markets by the end of 2008, which will embrace all relevant dimensions (including the 
equity market, bond market, derivative market [including commodity], and money market) and 
facilitate  agreement  on  new  initiatives  to  address  policy,  legal,  regulatory,  supervisory, 
institutional, and capacity constraints. The team leader will be responsible for helping to develop 
a capital market development master plan (blueprint) with well-defined strategic objectives for 
2008-2018. Other proposed measures to develop the different segments of the market will be 
reviewed,  including  coordinating  with  the  Bank  of  Thailand  and  Securities  and  Exchange 
Commission  (SEC).  Strategies  adopted  by  other  developed  markets  (such  as  Australia; 
Canada; Hong Kong, China; and Republic of Korea) as well as those of regional economies 
need to be taken into consideration. The blueprint will focus on the development of the equity 
and bond markets in Thailand. The team will also actively coordinate with the Debt Market 
Development Committee for actions proposed to improve the domestic bond market. 
 
3.  In coordination with the legal and regulatory expert, risk management expert, taxation 
expert, public debt management expert, and exchange control policy expert, the team leader will 
(i) review all existing plans for development of the capital market, including the capital market 
master plans 1 and 2, (ii) identify impediments to development of the Thai capital market, 
(iii) draft  the  strategic  blueprint  of  the  capital market  development  plan,  and  (iv)  a  draft a 
sequenced implementation plan over the next 10 years with performance indicators for each 
measure. The team leader will focus on the following main deliverables in addition to measures 
that the team may consider necessary for inclusion under the blueprint: 
 
(i)  Deepen  the  securities  market  by  (a)  enhancing  the  efficiency  of  resource 
mobilization, (b) expanding the government bond, (c) developing the corporate 
bond market as a competitive source of financing, (d) improving liquidity and 
market efficiency for secondary trading of securities, (e) developing mechanisms 
for financing of physical infrastructure—provision of long-term capital, and (f) 
encouraging the creation of venture capital and private equity funds. 
(ii)  Offer high quality securities, including risk management, through new products: 
(a) developing the derivative industry—bond futures, interest rate, exchange rate 
derivatives, equity derivatives, etc.; (b) introducing a wide range of capital market 
products, including structured products-new product development and strategic 
linkages with other market centers in the region; and (c) introducing measures for 
increasing the supply of securities, including progress on Privatization Act (1999). 
 
(iii)  Expand  investor  base  and  improve  measures  for  investor  protection  and 
education by (a) improving corporate governance and the governance of market 
institutions,  (b)  improving  disclosure  standards,  (c)  protecting  the  interest  of

12  Appendix 3 
minority  shareholders,  (d)  improving  and  strengthening  the  investment 
management industry, (e) enhancing the role of institutional investors (such as 
government pension funds and the insurance industry) by promoting a broader 
scope of investment activity, and (f) improving measures for investor protection 
and education. 
(iv)  Improve competition and enhance market intermediaries and related institutions, 
including  supporting  market  infrastructure  through  (a)  restructuring  the  Stock 
Exchange of Thailand (SET) with options for demutualization, as proposed by 
SET  based  on  the  study  being  carried  out  by  Boston  Consulting  Group; 
(b) enhancing the efficiency of market infrastructure (such as the clearing and 
settlement  systems)  and  identifying  measures  to  link  with  global  markets; 
(c) defining the role of the Agricultural Futures Exchange of Thailand (AFET) and 
possible consolidation of Thailand Futures Exchange with AFET; (d) developing 
and  strengthening  the  skills  of  market  intermediaries  and  service  providers 
anchored on prudential standards; (e) reducing transaction cost; (f) reviewing 
laws  and  tax  privileges  to  encourage  merger  and  acquisition  activities;  and 
(g) fostering alliances with other regional markets. 
(v)  Improve regulation and coordination by (a) reviewing all existing laws related to 
capital market development, including the Foreign Business Act, (1999) Board of 
Investment Law; and identifying legal and regulatory issues that regulators must 
address to ensure effective oversight and enforcement capabilities, and to align 
the framework for regulation with current global standards or best practices to 
facilitate integration with global markets; (b) ensuring that the framework keeps 
pace with the evolution of the business environment, new products, and regional 
initiatives aimed at harmonization of laws and integration of capital markets; 
(c) recommending concrete steps that need to be taken to ensure a financial 
governance  structure  that  achieves  optimal  coordination  among  regulators 
regarding supervision, regulation, and consumer protection in order to achieve 
the  objectives  of  capital  market  development  set  forth  in  the  master  plan; 
(d) identifying possible opportunities for harmonization of financial regulations; 
achieving better exchanges of information and data among regulators; and, from 
a macro perspective, developing a strategy for pursuing future reforms that cut 
across the current governance structure; and (e) moving from a merit-based to a 
disclosure-based regulatory system. 
(vi)  Recommend measures for a tax neutral financial market. Based on the study 
carried out under the earlier TA,1 help develop a liquid and integrated capital 
market with a tax system that meets the needs of different market participants 
and encourages savings and investments. It will form part of the capital market 
master  plan  exercise  and  will  develop  a  well-defined  tax  implementation 
framework that will help determine the impact of the recommended tax reforms 
and introduce a level playing field across products and institutions. The overall 
objective is to recommend a tax-neutral financial market where the interests of 
the Government and market players are preserved and balanced. The scope of 
work includes the following: (a) reviewing all major tax-related issues in the bank 
and nonbank sectors; (b) identifying products/transactions/undertakings where 
tax arbitrage may exist; (c) interacting with stakeholders to solicit inputs; and 
(d) recommending  possible  changes  that  could  improve  tax  neutrality;  and 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Thailand for Supporting the Implementation of the Capital 
Market Development Master Plan. Manila.

Appendix 3  13 
considering or citing international experience and best practices on the treatment 
of comparable products, transactions, and undertakings. 
(vii)  Other tasks: In coordination with the capital market legal and regulatory expert, 
risk management expert, and public debt management expert, support the capital 
markets institutional and training expert in carrying out the tasks outlined under 
para. 15 (ii) (a) of the main text. The main task will be to strengthen the technical 
knowledge and skills of staff in the Bureau of Savings and Investment Policy of 
the Fiscal Policy Office to interact effectively with other involved government 
agencies/market intermediaries in the capital market as well as more monitor the 
development of the capital markets in Thailand constructively. 
 
B.  International Capital Market Legal and Regulatory Expert (3 person-months) 
 
4.  This expert should have significant experience in capital market regulation in developed 
and developing markets, and a working knowledge of the implementation of the best practice 
principles  and  objectives  of  the  International  Organization  of  Securities  Commissions  in 
securities regulation. Experience in the Asia and Pacific region is preferable. The expert will 
support the team leader in developing the capital market master plan as well as the capital 
market institutional and training expert in carrying out the training component. The expert will: 
(i) examine the current regulatory framework and structure of the capital markets in Thailand, 
focusing on the efficacy of regulatory oversight mechanisms, enforcement and monitoring, and 
coordination among regulatory agencies; (ii) clarify gaps and impediments to the development 
of the capital market on the basis of best practice principles; (iii) support the team leader in all 
matters relating to laws and regulations in the capital market; (iv) assist the team leader in 
organizing and implementing workshops and seminars where legal and regulatory issues are 
discussed; and (v) prepare a work plan, progress reports, and deliverables as required by the 
team leader. The principal aim of this assignment will be to identify measures to be incorporated 
in  the  capital  market  master  plan  that  will  strengthen  the  regulatory  framework  governing 
Thailand’s capital market. This will involve setting suitable supervisory policies, rationalizing 
institutional responsibilities  across different  products  and  sectors,  and  identifying  any  legal 
implications.   
 
C.  International  Capital  Markets  Products  Risk  Management  Expert  (2.5  person-
months) 
 
5.  The  consultant  will  be  a  risk  management  expert  with  extensive  experience  in 
developing and trading in risk management and derivative products. The expert will support the 
team  leader  in  developing  the  capital  market  master  plan  as  well  as  the  capital  market 
institutional and training expert in carrying out the training component. For inclusion in the 
master plan, the expert will help the team leader identify measures for (i) developing the 
corporate bond market as a competitive source of financing; (ii) improving liquidity and market 
efficiency  for  secondary  trading  of  securities;  (iii)  developing  the  derivative  industry—bond 
futures, interest rate, exchange rate derivatives, equity derivatives, etc.; (iv) introducing a wide 
range of capital market products, including structured products-new product development; and 
(v) defining the role of AFET and consolidating the Thailand Futures Exchange with AFET. 
 
D.  International Taxation Experts (2) (2.5 person-months each) 
 
6.  One of the international experts should have an extensive background in financial sector 
tax and legal matters, and should be experienced in the implications of taxation of financial 
instruments on financial sector development. The second expert should be based in Thailand 
with extensive background and experience in taxation of financial instruments in southeast Asia,

14  Appendix 3 
particularly Thailand. The taxation experts should coordinate with the team leader as well as the 
other consultants to address financial sector tax issues. Based on the study carried out under 
the earlier TA2 the experts will help develop a liquid and integrated capital market by identifying 
a tax system that meets the needs of different market participants and encourages savings and 
investments. The proposed tax system will form part of the capital market master plan exercise 
and will develop a well-defined tax implementation framework that will help determine the 
impact of the recommended tax reforms and introduce a level playing field across products and 
institutions. The experts will recommend how to make tax treatment consistent with international 
accounting standards. They will support the team leader in carrying out the main tasks detailed 
in the terms of reference of the team leader for the tax component.  
 
7.  Other Tasks. The TA consulting team will conduct workshops as required, involving 
government agencies and other key stakeholders in the course of developing the draft capital 
market master plan. It will make periodical presentations to the Capital Market Development 
Committee on the progress of the draft plan. It will also recommend a sequenced, time-bound 
implementation schedule for the master plan. 
 
E.  (i) International Public Debt Management/Cash Management Expert  
                (2.5 person-months)  
  (ii) International State-Owned Enterprise Lending and Guarantee Expert  
                (1.5 person-months) 
 
8.  The debt management expert will have solid experience in all aspects of public debt and 
cash management expert and knowledge of best international practices in establishing a bond 
market development fund. The experts main task will be to (i) assist in framing investment 
guidelines for the fund in the short and medium term; (ii) help develop an accounting system 
and procedures to operate the fund on a sustainable basis; (iii) develop a training program that 
will build capacity among existing Public Debt Management Office (PDMO) staff in active asset 
and  liability  practices—investigate  the  suitability  of  sponsoring  staff  to  other 
established sovereign investment funds or placement in the private sector; (iv) compare the 
operation and construction of other funds to determine international best practice; (v) establish 
cash management monitoring systems to help PDMO and/or the Government optimize the 
investment of surpluses, and streamline bond issuing procedures—this includes exploring the 
feasibility of deposit proceeds from bond issuance (both deficit and surplus issuance) with 
commercial banks instead of the BOT; (vi) help develop a suitable a debt consolidation and 
issuance strategy for government debt as well steps to streamline the government bond auction 
process; and (vii) assist the capital market development expert and team leader in coordination 
with the other international experts in developing the capital market master plan. The state-
owned enterprise (SOE) expert will (i) help establish a framework and procedures for onlending 
and guarantees to SOEs and local government units, including concentration limits and lending 
criteria; lending and guarantee practices will need to be established that consider assessments 
of the creditworthiness of each SOE and local government unit, and reduce the risk of politically 
motivated lending practices; and (ii) recommend an internal credit rating and risk assessment 
process and pricing model for onlending to SOEs. 
 
F.  International Capital Market Institutional Expert (2 person-months) 
 
9.  The specialist will have first-rate experience and credentials in enhancing the knowledge 
and understanding of capital market principles and operations, and very good experience in 
                                                 
2  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Thailand for Supporting the Implementation of the Capital 
Market Development Master Plan. Manila.

Appendix 3  15 
carrying out training on capital market development. In coordination with the team leader as well 
as the other consultants working under the TA project, the expert will do the following: (i) design 
and conduct suitable training to provide the staff of the Fiscal Policy Office (FPO) with working 
knowledge of the importance of capital markets to domestic economic growth, and the role and 
responsibilities of the Government and other sectors to foster such development; (ii) focus on 
building  and  understanding  financial  markets,  financial  regulations,  and  trends  in  financial 
integration;  (iii)  train  FPO  staff  in  transparency,  accountability,  disclosure  policies,  and 
accounting  standards  regarding  financial  market  development;  (iv)  enhance  participants’ 
conceptual  understanding  and  practical  skills  in  capital  market  development;  and  discuss 
conceptual and practical policy issues concerning capital market development, particularly the 
bond market; and (v) share best practices and information that would be beneficial to develop 
and  manage  the  capital  market  in  Thailand,  the  analytical  framework  for  capital  market 
development, institutional and legal settings, infrastructure issues, and strategies and policy 
recommendations.  
 
G.  International Auditing Expert (1 person-month) 
 
10.  The expert will have a strong background in International Auditing Standards and be 
familiar  with  capital  market  operations.  He/she  should  be  fully  familiar  with  International 
Accounting Standards and best practices in the disclosure of financial information. The expert 
will (i) review the capacities of regulators to assess the quality of audits, (ii) help SEC design 
procedures  for  an  independent  review  of  audit  practices  adopted  by  auditors  of  listed 
companies, their work process and systems including developing relevant databases, format of 
reporting, internal quality assurance system, and enforcement; and (iii) conduct training for SEC 
on compliance with the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and the quality 
control system in accordance with ISA220 and ISQC1.3 
 
H.  International Secondary Mortgage Institutional and Policy Expert   
           (2.5 person-months) 
  
11.  This expert will be an experienced primary and secondary mortgage consultant, with 
significant experience in the operation of secondary mortgage facilities in markets comparable 
to Thailand. The expert will possess knowledge of the institutional framework and setting up of 
secondary  mortgage  facilities,  understanding  of  developed  and  developing  markets’ 
background, and experience of the Thai mortgage financing and capital market. The first task 
will be to carry out a complete diagnostic assessment and holistic evaluation of the role of the 
Secondary Mortgage Corporation (SMC) in the context of the primary housing market and 
secondary  mortgage  market  securitization  market  for  mortgage  receivables  in  Thailand. 
Through this evaluation exercise, the expert will determine if SMC has a role to play in the 
development of the capital market in Thailand, and if so, define the changes required in its legal 
charter, product range, organizational structure, and capital resources to make it a sustainable 
and viable entity. The expert will identify hurdles and remedies for successful SMC operations. 
He/she  will  also  develop  a  sustainable  business  model  for  SMC  operations,  identify  the 
technical and human resources required by SMC to implement the recommended operations, 
recommend  the  ideal  organizational  structure  for  SMC  to  carry  out  the  recommended 
operations,  and  conduct  and  facilitate  market  discussion  forums  for  public  education  of 
secondary mortgage financing.  
                                                 
3  International Standard on Auditing (ISA) 220, Quality Control for an Audit of Financial Statements and International 
Standard  on  Quality  Control  (ISQC)1,  Quality  Control  for  firms  that  perform  audit  and  review  of  financial 
statements.

16  Appendix 3 
 
I.  International Mortgage Insurance Development Expert (2 person-months) 
 
12.  This expert will be an experienced mortgage insurance development consultant, with 
significant experience in (i) development of  mortgage insurance in markets comparable to 
Thailand;  (ii)  institutional  framework  and  setup  of  mortgage  guarantee  products;  and 
(iii) developed and developing markets’ background, and understanding of the Thai  mortgage 
insurance and capital market. The main tasks will be to (i) carry out a comparative study of the 
important features of mortgage insurance in other countries in Asia (such as Hong Kong, China; 
Indonesia; India; Malaysia; Russian Federation; and Singapore) as well as the United States 
and Europe; (ii) recommend how to establish an active and well-organized mortgage insurance 
market  in  Thailand,  including  an  effective  implementation  plan;  this  should  contain  the 
regulatory framework, structure and sponsorship (government or private), scope of coverage, 
etc.;  (iii)  help  develop  information/database  necessary  for  accessing  borrowers’ 
creditworthiness; (iv) carry out a market survey to determine whether levying of pricing for such 
guarantee is necessary as this will be loaded to the borrowing cost by lenders; (v) market 
survey should also include what form of guarantee will be acceptable, whether it should be in 
the form of an indemnity or a conditional guarantee; and (vi) list steps to introduce foreclosure 
laws and their enforcement. 
 
J.  International Exchange Control Policy Expert (2 person-months) 
 
13.  The expert should have extensive experience in advising on how to balance conflicting 
policy objectives of developing capital/financial markets while ensuring the ability to manage 
speculative capital inflows effectively through long-term policy consideration. The main tasks will 
be to (i) advise on the implications of capital control measures to financial market development; 
(ii) share the experience of Thailand as well as other countries on the cost, benefit, and role of 
nonresidents  in  the  development  of  financial  markets;  (iii)  advise  on  the  importance  of 
nonresidents’ participation in the development of financial markets; (iv) advise the pros and 
cons of non-deliverable forward markets; (v) advise on how best to regulate nonresidents’ 
participation in the financial markets; (vi) share other countries’ experiences in balancing the two 
policy  objectives;  and  (vii)  review  the  “Foreign  Exchange  Regulations”  and  “  Measures  to 
Prevent Thai Baht Speculation” and recommend policy measures to serve the two objectives. 
 
K.  National Consultants—Financial Sector/Capital Markets Expert (4 person-months), 
Mortgage Finance Expert (2 person-months), Insurance Expert (2 person-months)  
 
14.  The national experts will have backgrounds in economic analysis, understanding of bond 
and capital markets, the regulatory structure and operations of Thai’s financial sector, mortgage 
finance, and the insurance sector. They should have proficiency in English. In addition to the 
tasks outlined below, the national experts will act as TA project coordinators and assist the 
international consultants in all matters of project coordination and logistics.  
 
L.  National Project Coordinator (5 person-months) 
 
15.  The expert should have very good proficiency in English and act as overall project 
coordinator, providing support to all aspects of TA implementation.
